segments.text: For centuries, electricity and magnetism were seen as two separate forces. In this lesson, we will explore the groundbreaking discovery that linked them forever and learn how to visualize the invisible fields they create.
This all changed in 1820 with Danish scientist Hans Christian Oersted.

During a lecture, he made an accidental discovery that would change the world. He used a simple setup, a straight wire connected to a battery placed directly over a compass. Initially, with the circuit open, nothing happens. But the moment he closed the switch, allowing current to flow through the wire, the compass needle moved.

This proved that an electric current creates a magnetic effect. This region of influence created by the current is called a magnetic field. It's an invisible area of force that surrounds any magnet or current carrying wire.
To understand these invisible fields, we use a tool called magnetic field lines. These are imaginary lines that show us the structure of the magnetic field.

Field lines have a specific direction. By convention, they always point away from the magnet's north pole and loop around to enter the south pole. The closeness of the lines tells us about the field's strength. Where the lines are crowded together, like near the poles, the magnetic field is very strong. A crucial rule is that magnetic field lines can never cross each other.
This is because at any single point, the magnetic field can only have one direction.
So, to recap, electric currents create magnetic fields.
We visualize these fields using lines that show direction and strength, emerge from north to south, and never, ever cross.
